Deontological ethics or deontology (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] {{lang|grc|δέον}}, ''deon'', "obligation, duty"; and {{lang|grc|-λογία}}, ''[[-logy|-logia]]'') is an approach to [[ethics]] that determines goodness or rightness from examining [[acts]], rather than third-party [[consequences]] of the act as in [[consequentialism]], or the [[intention]]s of the person doing the act as in [[virtue ethics]]. Deontologists look at rules name="plato.stanford.edu">[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ethics-virtue/]</ref> and duties. For example, the act may be considered the right thing to do even if it produces a bad consequence<ref>Olson, Robert G. 1967. 'Deontological Ethics'. In Paul Edwards (ed.) ''The Encyclopedia of Philosophy''. London: Collier Macmillan: 343.</ref>, if it follows the ''rule'' that “one should do unto others as they would have done unto them”<ref name="plato.stanford.edu">[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ethics-virtue/]</ref>, and even if the person who does the act lacks virtue and had a bad intention in doing the act{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}. We have a ''duty'' to act in a way that does those things that are [[inherently]] good as acts ("truth-telling" for example), or follow an objectively obligatory rule (as in [[rule utilitarianism]]). For deontologists, the ends or consequences of our actions are not important in and of themselves, and our intentions are not important in and of themselves.
